results.byline: By Aatish Taseer and Richard Mosse
results.title: In Search of a Lost Spain
results.abstract: In the southern part of the country, churches and streets hold the remnants of eight centuries of Islamic rule.

media.caption: The ceiling of the Hall of Ambassadors in the Alcazar in Seville, Spain. Built by Peter I of Castile (1334-69), the structure is an example of the Mudéjar style of architecture, in which Islamic ornamentation and building techniques were overlaid with Christian meaning.

results.adx_keywords: Music;Content Type: Personal Profile;Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;internal-sub-only;Streisand, Barbra
results.title: Barbra Streisand on Her Pristine Early Recordings: ‘That Girl Can Sing’
results.abstract: “Live at the Bon Soir,” a restored set of songs from November 1962, allows listeners today — and Streisand, herself — to rediscover the sounds of a star being born.

media.caption: Barbra Streisand onstage at the Bon Soir in the West Village. A collection of her newly restored recordings from the small West Village club is being released as “Live at the Bon Soir.”

results.byline: By Kim Severson and Julia Moskin
results.title: Julie Powell, Food Writer Known for ‘Julie & Julia,’ Dies at 49
results.abstract: She attempted to cook every recipe in a classic Julia Child cookbook and documented the effort in a popular blog that became a best-selling book and a hit movie.

results.title: ‘Fast Furniture’ Is Cheap. And Americans Are Throwing It in the Trash.
results.abstract: The mass-produced furniture that sold furiously during the pandemic could soon be clogging landfills.

media.caption: Consumers in the United States spent $4 billion more on desks, chairs and patio equipment in 2021 than they did in 2019. Environmentalists say that a lot of the products sold during the pandemic weren’t built to last.
media.copyright: John Taggart for The New York Times.

results.title: Republicans, Eyeing Majority, Float Changes to Social Security and Medicare
results.abstract: Democrats have seized on Republican proposals to limit retirement benefits to galvanize voters ahead of the midterm elections.

media.caption: Senator Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, has proposed subjecting nearly all federal spending programs to a renewal vote every year, which would make Medicare and Social Security more vulnerable to budget cuts.

results.title: The Pandemic Generation Goes to College. It Has Not Been Easy.
results.abstract: Students missed a lot of high school instruction. Now many are behind, especially in math, and getting that degree could be harder.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Cartoons and Cartoonists;Dogs;Cats;Booth, George;New Yorker
results.title: George Booth, New Yorker Cartoonist of Sublime Zaniness, Dies at 96
results.abstract: He depicted a quirky cast of people and pets — notably his mad-as-a-hatter bull terrier, which became a reader favorite and the magazine’s unofficial mascot.

media.caption: The longtime New Yorker cartoonist George Booth, right, with the magazine’s cartoon editor at the time, Robert Mankoff, in 2001. In a half century at the magazine, Mr. Booth drew roughly a score of covers and hundreds of cartoons for the inside pages.
